column4: anybody know how to change ownership of files/directory of NTFS drive, without going through Windows XP?  i.e. straight from ubuntu
if you mean mount permissions, then yer fstab
nope, but i want to read some files in user directories after mounting them.
when you mount, everything should be accessible
yes everything is accessible.  but i tried to scp some data in a user directory out, and it says "permission denied"
other files outside user directory can be scp-ed out
whats the ownership for those files?
NTFS -> ext3 is what you are trying to do?
yes
i think they are under some non-administrative user account on winxp
when NTFS is mounted on Linux, root becomes the owner of all the files, unless you specify otherwise
so, there should be zero restrictions on copy operations on NTFS part
perhaps the destination is the issue?
that's right.  but i can access some of the root files, but not some (eventhough their file permissions are the same)
specifically, those under the user directories, i.e. Document and Settings/someguy/*  cannot be accessed.
everything else outside Document and Setting/ ../ etc can be
try mounting with umask=000
ok i'll give that a shot.
you could try using NTFS-3G to mount ro, i know for a fact that on Linux the NTFS ACLs are ignored
i hope so! :)
that's what i've been reading on forums, but i'm getting all these access denied.  so i'm trying knoppix now.
are you sure the destination isn't the issue?
yup, because i copied some other files from other non-restricted directories, and those worked fine.
i guess try ntfs-3g, weird
